lines.content: * The Deadline class represents a task with a specific deadline.
* It extends the Task class and includes a due date and time.
* Constructs a Deadline task with the given description and due date.
* @param description The description of the task.
* @param by The date and time by which the task should be completed.
* Returns a string representation of the Deadline task, including its status, description,
* @return A string in the format "[D][status] description (by: due date)".
* Returns a string representation of the Deadline task in a format suitable for data storage.
* @return A string in the format "D | status | description | due date".
super("OOPS!!! I think you forgot to type something.");
super("OOPS!!! The description of a task cannot be empty.");
* The Event class represents a task that occurs within a specific time frame.
* It extends the Task class and includes a start time and an end time.
* Constructs an Event task with the given description, start time, and end time.
* @param description The description of the event.
* @param from The start date and time of the event.
* @param to The end date and time of the event.
public Event(String description, LocalDateTime from, LocalDateTime to) {
* Returns a string representation of the Event task, including its status, description,
* @return A string in the format "[E][status] description (from: start time to: end time)".
return String.format("[E]%s (from: %s to: %s)", super.toString(), from.format(formatter), to.format(formatter));
* Returns a string representation of the Event task in a format suitable for data storage.
* @return A string in the format "E | status | description | start time-end time".
* The Fred class serves as the main class for a task management application.
* It initializes essential components such as Storage, TaskList, Ui, and Parser,
* and provides methods to run the application, execute user actions, and handle
* tasks like adding, marking, or deleting tasks.
* Constructs a new Fred object and initializes the Storage, TaskList, Ui, and Parser components.
* Runs the Fred application. This method loads tasks from the storage, greets the user,
* and enters a loop to process user inputs and execute corresponding actions.
* The main method to start the Fred application.
* Exits the Fred application by terminating the program.
* Executes the user action based on the parsed input. The method supports
* various actions such as adding a task, marking it as done or not done,
* deleting a task, and printing the task list.
* @param action A String array containing the action and its parameters.
* @throws FredException If the action is invalid or cannot be executed.
message = String.format("Nice! I've marked this task as done:\n" +
message = String.format("OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:\n" +
message = String.format("Noted. I've removed this task:\n" +
message = String.format("Got it. I've added this task:\n" +
"Now you have %d tasks in the list.", task, tasks.getTaskListSize());
super("OOPS!!! That's not a valid task number!");
* The Parser class handles the parsing of user input. It converts raw input strings
* into structured commands that can be executed by the application. The parser
* identifies and processes various commands, throwing exceptions for invalid inputs.
* Parses the user's input string and returns an array representing the command and its arguments.
* @param input The raw input string entered by the user.
* @return A String array where the first element is the command, and subsequent elements are arguments.
* @throws FredException If the input is invalid or contains an unknown command.
* The Storage class handles the creation, reading, updating, and deletion of data
* from a persistent storage file. It manages tasks stored in a file and allows
* the application to load and save tasks between sessions.
* Ensures that the data file and its directory exist. If not, they are created.
* Retrieves tasks from the data file and returns them as an ArrayList of Task objects.
* @return An ArrayList containing the tasks read from the data file.
task = new Event(lineParts[2], LocalDateTime.parse(fromTo[0], formatter), LocalDateTime.parse(fromTo[1], formatter));
* Deletes a specific task from the data file by rewriting the file without the specified task.
* @param taskNumber The index of the task to be deleted from the data file.
* Appends a new task to the data file.
* @param task The task to be added to the data file.
* The abstract Task class represents a task with a description and a completion status.
* It provides methods for marking the task as done or not done, and for generating
* a string representation of the task for both display and data storage purposes.
* Constructs a Task with the given description. By default, the task is not done.
* @param description The description of the task.
* Returns the status icon of the task.
* @return "X" if the task is done, otherwise a space (" ").
* Marks the task as not done.
* Returns a string representation of the task, including its status and description.
* @return A string in the format "[status] description".
* Returns a string representation of the task in a format suitable for data storage.
* @return A string representing the task's data format, indicating its status and description.
* The TaskList class manages a collection of Task objects. It provides functionality
* to create tasks, add them to the list, mark them as done or not done, delete them,
* and load tasks from an external data source.
* Creates a new task based on the type and details provided by the user.
* @param taskType The type of task to create ("todo", "deadline", or "event").
* @param taskDetails The details of the task, including description and any time-related information.
* Adds a task to the task list.
* @param task The task to be added to the list.
* @param taskNumber The index of the task to be marked as done.
* @return The task that was marked as done.
* @throws FredException If the task number is invalid.
* Marks a task as not done.
* @param taskNumber The index of the task to be marked as not done.
* @return The task that was marked as not done.
* @throws FredException If the task number is invalid.
* Deletes a task from the task list.
* @param taskNumber The index of the task to be deleted.
* @throws FredException If the task number is invalid.
* Loads tasks into the task list from an external data source.
* @param tasks The list of tasks to be loaded into the task list.
* Gets the number of tasks in the task list.
* @return The size of the task list.
* The Todo class represents a basic task without any specific time or deadline.
* It extends the Task class and is used for tasks that need to be done but are not time-bound.
* Constructs a Todo task with the given description.
* @param description The description of the task.
* Returns a string representation of the Todo task, including its status and description.
* @return A string in the format "[T][status] description".
* Returns a string representation of the Todo task in a format suitable for data storage.
* @return A string in the format "T | status | description".
* The Ui class handles all user interactions, including printing messages
* to the console and receiving user input. It is responsible for greeting the user,
* printing task lists, and displaying messages in a consistent format.
* Constructs a new Ui object and initializes the scanner for user input.
* Displays a message to the user, surrounded by horizontal lines for formatting.
* @param message The message to be displayed to the user.
* Greets the user with a welcome message when the application starts.
String message = "Hello! I'm Fred\nWhat can I do for you?";
* Bids farewell to the user when the application is about to exit.
String message = "Bye. Hope to see you again soon!";
* Prints the list of tasks provided by the user in a formatted manner.
* @param taskList The list of tasks to be printed.
* Retrieves input from the user via the console.
* @return The input entered by the user as a String.
System.out.println("Here are the matching tasks in your list:");
super("OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I don't know what that means :-(");
String[] actual = new Parser().parseInput("todo return book");
assertEquals("OOPS!!! The description of a task cannot be empty.", e.getMessage());
assertEquals("OOPS!!! That's not a valid task number!", e.getMessage());
assertEquals("OOPS!!! That's not a valid task number!", e.getMessage());
assertEquals("OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I don't know what that means :-(", e.getMessage());
assertEquals("T | 0 | return book", new Todo("return book").getDataFormat());
assertEquals("[T][ ] return book", new Todo("return book").toString());
